The Auto Backup feature in the Gruhanaksha QGIS plugin provides comprehensive automatic backup functionality for your QGIS projects and data layers. It ensures that your work is regularly saved and protected against data loss, with flexible scheduling and selective layer backup options.
The Master Panel is a user-friendly form in QGIS designed to help you easily enter and manage administrative details such as:
This tool allows you to easily move polygon vertices or adjust side lengths directly on your QGIS map using a guided, click-based process. It's designed for simplicity, precision, and clarity.

The Property Parcel Map Generator is a QGIS Processing Algorithm that automates the generation of parcel-wise Property Parcel Maps. It uses plot and built-up shapefiles to generate map-ready outputs with symbology, labels, and atlas setup.

The Tools Panel is a floating window in the Gruhanaksha QGIS plugin that provides quick access to a suite of specialized tools for land surveying, mapping, and data management. It serves as a central hub for activating various widgets and tools essential for cadastral and geometric operations.
Help us improve our documentation by reporting errors or suggesting improvements.
You don't need React to write simple standalone pages.

Contribution Thank you for expressing interest in contributing to Surveyor Stories and their associated projects We want to clarify that while we greatly appreciate contributions, we do not offer any monetary compensation. Instead, we welcome passionate individuals who are willing to offer their skills, expertise, or resources to support our initiatives. Your valuable contributions towards Surveyor Stories will help uphold and enrich without any expectation of financial rewards. Loading‚Ä¶

Gruhanaksha is a specialized QGIS plugin developed to support the preparation, validation, and finalization of geospatial deliverables under the SVAMITVA (Survey of Villages and Mapping with Improvised Technology in Village Areas) scheme. It streamlines the workflows for SVAMITVA Team by offering tools for: Generating map outputs as per SVAMITVA standards Integrating field inputs and updated survey data Producing deliverables such as property cards, ownership maps, and attribute reports
Get started by Downloading the Plugin from Gruhanaksha web or from here üåµ Prerequisites Gruhanaksha requires QGIS version 3.26 or newer for compatibility and functionality.
Click on Download Loading... Old Releases No old releases available. All Releases button Locate the plugin file you want to install in your PC(Laptop). The plugin file is usually in ZIP file format
Launch the QGIS(>2.26) application on your computer. In the QGIS menu, go to "Plugins" Click on "Manage and Install Plugins". In the Plugin Manager window, go to the "Installed" tab.

Click on the "Install from ZIP" button. Browse your computer to select the Gruhanaksha plugin ZIP file you want to install. Click "Install Plugin." Once installed, you may need to enable the plugin by checking the box next to its name. Close the Plugin Manager. success Yeah, you did it! üöÄ You're now armed with incredible new tools at your fingertips. Let the adventure begin!

Available from v1.0.1 The Professional Line Tool is an advanced QGIS plugin that provides enhanced line drawing capabilities with precise measurement, angle control, and circle creation features. It's designed for surveyors, engineers, and GIS professionals who need accurate geometric drawing tools.
QGIS with an active, editable vector layer (line geometry) Layer must be in edit mode
Click on Advanced line Icon in the toolbar The tool will be activated on your map canvas

Key üéØ Function üìù Description L üìè Length/Parameters Open parameter dialog for precise length/angle input O üìê Ortho Mode Toggle orthogonal drawing (constrains to 45¬∞ increments) A üîí Angle Lock Cycle: 90¬∞ Lock ‚Üí 180¬∞ Lock ‚Üí Off (double-tap to cancel) R ‚≠ï Circle Mode Toggle between line drawing and circle drawing modes Q üìä Units Cycle Switch between: Meters ‚Üí Metric Links ‚Üí Gunter Links ‚Üí Feet ‚Üí Yards S üéØ Snap Toggle Enable/disable snapping to layers and vertices U ‚Ü©Ô∏è Undo Point Remove the last placed point from current line C üîÑ Close Line Connect current line back to start point (close polygon) Enter ‚úÖ Finish Line Complete and save the current line to layer Return ‚úÖ Finish Line Same as Enter - complete current line Escape ‚ùå Cancel Cancel current operation or exit preview mode
Action Function Left Click Add point / Start line / Confirm action Right Click Finish line / Open parameter dialog Mouse Move Preview line / Update cursor info

Start: Left-click to place first point Continue: Move mouse and left-click to add more points Press L to enter precise Length Finish: Right-click or press Enter to complete line Visual Feedback: üü¢ Green markers show placed points üß≤ Pink marker indicates snap points üìè Live length and angle display in cursor info

Press R to enter circle mode. Method 1: Center-Radius Left-click to set circle center Move mouse to desired radius Left-click to create circle Method 2: Center + Precise Radius Left-click to set circle center Press L to enter precise radius Enter radius value and click Apply

Press A to cycle through angle lock modes: First Press: üîí 90¬∞ Lock Constrains lines to 90¬∞ increments from previous segment For first segment: locks to cardinal directions (N, E, S, W) Second Press: üîí 180¬∞ Lock Constrains lines to 180¬∞ (parallel/perpendicular) For first segment: locks to N-S or E-W axes Third Press: ‚ùå Cancel Lock Returns to free drawing Double-tap A: Quick cancel of current lock
Press O to toggle ortho mode: Constrains all lines to 45¬∞ increments Works independently of angle lock Visual indicator in cursor info

Enter precise measurements: Length Input: üî¢ Precise length value üîÑ Auto-converts between units üìä Supports 5 unit types Angle Input: ‚òëÔ∏è Enable "Use Angle" checkbox üéØ Enter angle in degrees (0¬∞ = North, clockwise) üéÆ Quick angle buttons: 0¬∞, 45¬∞, 90¬∞, 135¬∞, 180¬∞, 225¬∞, 270¬∞, 315¬∞

Press Q to cycle through supported units: Unit Name Symbol Conversion Factor m Meters m 1.0 mli Metric Links Metric 0.2 li Gunter Links Gunter 0.201168 ft Feet ft 0.3048 yd Yards yd 0.9144 Features: üîÑ Automatic conversion between units üíæ Values preserved when switching units üìä Live display in cursor info

The tool provides intelligent snapping: QGIS Layer Snapping: üéØ Respects project snapping settings üîß Toggle with S key Custom Vertex Snapping: üü¢ Automatically snaps to your drawn points üéØ Only active when QGIS snapping is enabled üß≤ Pink marker indicates snap target

The live cursor info shows: üìè Length: Current segment length in selected units üìê Angle: Direction in degrees (N=0¬∞ clockwise) üéÆ Mode: Current drawing mode/state üéØ Snap Status: ON/OFF + Vertex indication üìä Unit: Currently selected unit Auto-scaling Display: Values < 1: Show 4 decimal places Values < 1000: Show 3 decimal places Values ‚â• 1000m: Auto-convert to kilometers

1. Set units to feet: Press Q until "Feet" is selected 2. Start at corner: Left-click first point 3. Enter precise distance: Press L, enter "150 ft", Apply 4. Move mouse to direction and click to confirm 5. Use angle lock: Press A for 90¬∞ constraint 6. Continue adding segments with precise measurements 7. Close boundary: Press C to connect back to start

1. Enable ortho mode: Press O 2. Start at building corner: Left-click 3. Draw first wall: Move mouse east, left-click 4. Use angle lock: Press A for 90¬∞ increments 5. Continue around building perimeter 6. Use parameter dialog: Press L for precise room dimensions 7. Finish: Press Enter when complete

1. Enter circle mode: Press R 2. Click center point of circular feature 3. For precise radius: Press L, enter radius value 4. For visual radius: Move mouse and click at desired edge 5. Return to line mode: Press R again

Tool won't activate: ‚úÖ Ensure you have an active vector layer ‚úÖ Layer must have line geometry type ‚úÖ Layer must be in edit mode No cursor info display: üñ±Ô∏è Move mouse over the canvas üîÑ Tool activates on canvas focus Snapping not working: üéØ Check QGIS project snapping settings üîß Press S to toggle tool snapping ‚öôÔ∏è Verify layer snapping configuration Parameter dialog issues: üìè Ensure positive length values üîÑ Check unit conversions are reasonable ‚úÖ Click Apply button to confirm

üéØ Accuracy: Use parameter dialog (L) for precise measurements ‚ö° Speed: Use angle lock (A) for repetitive geometric patterns üîß Workflow: Enable ortho mode (O) for architectural drawings üìä Units: Set appropriate units before starting complex drawings üíæ Save Often: Remember to save your edits regularly
Color Meaning Green Box Placed vertex points Pink Box Active snap point Gray Dashed Preview line

Available from v2.1.0 This powerful tool allows you to align, rotate, and scale vector features (lines or polygons) with precision. It works by mapping two "source" vertices from your feature to two "target" points on the map, similar to a two-point georeferencing operation.

An editable Line or Polygon layer must be the active layer in QGIS. The layer must be in editing mode (pencil icon ‚úèÔ∏è activated). For best results, enable snapping in Project > Snapping Options... to accurately select points and vertices.

The tool follows a simple 4-click sequence to define the transformation: Click 1 (Target Point 1): Select the destination point on the map. Click 2 (Source Vertex 1): Select the vertex on your feature that should move to Target Point 1. Click 3 (Target Point 2): Select the second destination point. Click 4 (Source Vertex 2): Select the second vertex on your feature that should move to Target Point 2. Choose Operation: A dialog will ask if you want to Scale the feature to fit the new points or just Align Only (move and rotate). Transformation Applied: The feature is moved, rotated, and optionally scaled. The tool is immediately ready for another alignment.

Make sure your desired line or polygon layer is active and in editing mode. Activate the Aligner Tool from the plugin toolbar or menu. A message will appear: "Tool activated... Left-click to select points, right-click to reset."

Select Target Point 1: Left-click on the map where you want the first vertex to end up. You can snap to any existing geometry for precision. A red point marker will appear. The message bar will prompt: "First point selected. Select the corresponding feature vertex." Select Source Vertex 1: Left-click on the vertex of the feature you want to align. This is the point that will be moved to your first target point. A blue dashed line will appear, connecting the target point to the source vertex. The message bar will prompt: "First vertex detected... Select the second target point."
documents.s: üü© Step 2: Select the First Pair of Points

documents.t: Select Target Point 2: Left-click on the map to define the second destination point. A second red point marker will appear. The message bar will prompt: "Second target point selected... Select the second vertex from source layer." Select Source Vertex 2: Left-click on the second vertex of your feature. A second blue dashed line will appear.
documents.s: üü© Step 3: Select the Second Pair of Points

documents.t: Immediately after the fourth click, a dialog box will appear with three options: Scale: This will translate, rotate, and scale the feature. The distance between the two source vertices will be adjusted to match the distance between the two target points. Align Only: This will only translate and rotate the feature. The size and shape of the feature will be preserved. Cancel: Aborts the current operation.
After you make a choice, the feature is instantly transformed. The tool automatically resets and is ready for a new alignment operation, starting again from Step 2.

Multi-Feature Alignment: If you have multiple features selected in the layer before starting the alignment process, the same transformation will be applied to all of them. Resetting: A right-click at any time will cancel the current point selection and reset the tool, allowing you to start over. Snapping: This tool fully respects your project's snapping settings. Enable snapping to vertices and segments for the most accurate selections. Visual Feedback: Red Points: Your target destination points. Blue Dashed Lines: Show the mapping from your source vertices to your target points. Snap Indicator: A magenta cross shows when you are snapped to a vertex or segment.
Simply select any other tool from the QGIS toolbars (like the Pan or Select tool). The Aligner Tool will automatically deactivate.

Available from v1.0.1 The Enhanced Atlas Export Tool allows you to export print layouts and atlas pages in various formats with advanced customization options. Whether you're creating a single map or hundreds of atlas pages, this tool streamlines the export process with an intuitive interface and robust error handling.

üéØ Support for both atlas and single layout exports üìÅ Multiple export formats (PDF, PNG, JPG, TIFF, SVG) üîß Advanced quality and compression settings üëÄ Live preview capabilities üìä Comprehensive export logging
‚úÖ QGIS 3.26 installed ‚úÖ At least one print layout created in your project ‚úÖ For atlas exports: coverage layer configured
üìÇ Open your QGIS project üñ±Ô∏è Click on the Atlas Export icon or Plugins ‚ñ∂ Gruhanaksha ‚ñ∂ Atlas Export
The tool features a split-panel interface:

Layout Selection - Choose your print layout Export Mode - Select export type (all, custom, single) Output Settings - Configure directory and filenames Quality Settings - Adjust DPI, compression, and size Advanced Options - Vector settings, text rendering
Layout Preview - Visual preview of selected page Preview Information - Detailed layout and feature data Export Log - Real-time export progress and messages

Print Layout Dropdown üìù Lists all available print layouts in your project Shows "No layouts available" if none exist Atlas Status Display üó∫Ô∏è Shows current atlas configuration state Indicates coverage layer and feature count Enable/Disable Atlas üîò Toggle atlas functionality on/off Only visible when coverage layer is configured

‚úÖ "Atlas: Enabled (X features from 'LayerName')" - Ready for export ‚ö†Ô∏è "Atlas: Configured but not enabled" - Click "Enable Atlas" ‚ùå "Atlas: Enabled but no coverage layer set" - Configure coverage layer üìÑ "Regular Layout: No atlas configuration" - Single page layout
Use Case: Export one page from a regular (non-atlas) layout Button: "Export Single Layout" Output: One file per layout
Use Case: Export every page in the atlas Button: "Export All Pages" Output: One file per atlas feature Note: Only available for atlas-enabled layouts
Use Case: Export specific pages from atlas Button: "Export Custom Pages" Input Format: Single pages: 1,3,5 Ranges: 1-5,8,10-12 Mixed: 1,3,5-8,12,15-20
Single page export is automatically disabled for atlas layouts Atlas options are disabled for regular layouts
Browse Button üìÇ: Select destination folder Path Display: Shows selected directory path Auto-creation: Directory created automatically if it doesn't exist

Configure output filenames using placeholders: Standard Placeholders‚Äã {page} - Page number (001, 002, 003...) {index} - Zero-based index (0, 1, 2...) Atlas-Specific Placeholders‚Äã {field_name} - Value from coverage layer field Example: {NAME}, {ID}, {REGION} Example Patterns‚Äã atlas_{page} ‚Üí atlas_001.pdf, atlas_002.pdf map_{NAME}_{page} ‚Üí map_London_001.pdf, map_Paris_002.pdf export_{ID}_{index} ‚Üí export_12_0.pdf, export_15_1.pdf

Choose from five formats: Format Best For Vector Support Transparency PDF üìÑ Professional printing ‚úÖ Yes ‚ùå No PNG üñºÔ∏è Web use, transparency ‚ùå No ‚úÖ Yes JPG üì∑ Photos, smaller files ‚ùå No ‚ùå No TIFF üóÉÔ∏è GIS applications ‚ùå No ‚úÖ Yes SVG üé® Scalable graphics ‚úÖ Yes ‚úÖ Yes
Range: 72-1200 DPI Default: 300 DPI Recommendations: üì± Screen: 72-96 DPI üñ®Ô∏è Print: 300 DPI üìä High-quality: 600+ DPI
Range: 1-100% Default: 95% Slider Control: Real-time percentage display
Width/Height: Set custom pixel dimensions Auto Mode: Leave at 0 for automatic sizing Aspect Ratio: Maintains proportions when one dimension is set
PNG/TIFF Compression‚Äã Range: 0-9 (0=none, 9=maximum) Default: 6 Trade-off: Higher compression = smaller files, slower processing
‚úÖ Include Metadata: Embed creation info, timestamps üìÅ Create Subdirectories: Organize exports into folders

Two mutually exclusive options: Export as Vectors ‚úÖ (Recommended)‚Äã Benefits: Crisp text, scalable graphics, smaller files Best for: Maps with text labels, simple geometries Rasterize Whole Layout üñºÔ∏è‚Äã Benefits: Consistent appearance, complex effects Best for: Layouts with complex styling, raster backgrounds
Always Outlines üî§: Convert text to vector paths (reliable) Always Text üìã: Keep text as selectable text (smaller files)

Image Compression‚Äã Lossless/None: No compression, larger files Lossy (JPEG): Compressed images, smaller files JPEG Quality (when Lossy selected)‚Äã Range: 1-100% Default: 90% Applies to: Raster images embedded in PDF
Enable Preview Rendering ‚òëÔ∏è: Toggle visual preview on/off Page Selector üî¢: Choose which atlas page to preview Refresh Button üîÑ: Update preview manually
Always visible text panel showing: Layout name and type Atlas configuration status Feature count and coverage layer Current page attributes Export settings summary
When enabled, shows: Actual rendered layout/atlas page Scaled to fit preview area Error messages if rendering fails
üöÄ Disable visual preview for faster performance üìã Text info updates automatically üîÑ Use refresh if preview seems outdated
‚úÖ Configure all settings üëÄ Use "Preview" to verify settings ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Click "Export" to begin üìä Monitor progress bar and log
Progress Bar üìà: Shows completion percentage Export Log üìù: Detailed messages and file names Page Counter üî¢: "Exported X/Y pages"
üõë Click "Cancel" button during export üïê Wait for current page to finish üìÑ Partially exported files are preserved
‚úÖ Success: "Successfully exported X pages" ‚ùå Error: Specific error message with details ‚èπÔ∏è Cancelled: "Export cancelled. XX pages exported"

"No layouts available"‚Äã Cause: No print layouts in project Solution: üìã Create a print layout in QGIS üîÑ Refresh the tool "Atlas not enabled"‚Äã Cause: Atlas is configured but disabled Solution: üîò Click "Enable Atlas" button ‚úÖ Verify coverage layer is valid "No coverage layer configured"‚Äã Cause: Atlas enabled without coverage layer Solution: üó∫Ô∏è Open layout properties in QGIS üìç Set coverage layer in Atlas tab Export fails immediately‚Äã Causes & Solutions: üìÅ Invalid output directory: Check folder permissions üíæ Disk space: Ensure sufficient storage üîí File locks: Close files that might be open Preview shows "error"‚Äã Causes & Solutions: üó∫Ô∏è Invalid atlas page: Check page number üí• Rendering issues: Try disabling complex styling üîÑ Stale data: Click refresh button

Memory Errors‚Äã Message: "Not enough memory for export" Solution: üìâ Reduce DPI settings üìè Use smaller custom dimensions üóÇÔ∏è Export in smaller batches File Access Errors‚Äã Message: "Could not write to file" Solutions: üîë Check folder permissions üíæ Ensure disk space available üìù Verify filename is valid Atlas Errors‚Äã Message: "Failed to seek to page X" Solutions: üîç Check coverage layer validity üîÑ Refresh atlas in layout üìä Verify feature count matches
üöÄ Disable preview rendering for large atlases üìâ Use lower DPI for draft exports üóÇÔ∏è Export in batches for very large atlases üíæ Close other applications for memory-intensive exports

üìÇ Use descriptive folder names with dates üè∑Ô∏è Include field names in patterns for easy identification üìä Create subdirectories for different export types üóÉÔ∏è Archive old exports regularly
üì± Screen viewing: 150 DPI, PNG format üñ®Ô∏è Office printing: 300 DPI, PDF format üìä Professional printing: 600 DPI, PDF with vectors üåê Web publishing: 96 DPI, PNG with transparency

‚úÖ Test with small samples before full export üè∑Ô∏è Use meaningful field names in filename patterns üßπ Clean data to avoid invalid filename characters üîç Preview random pages to verify consistency
üíø Backup project files before major exports üìã Save export settings by documenting parameters üóÇÔ∏è Keep export logs for troubleshooting üîÑ Test recovery procedures with sample data

üéØ Start small: Test with 2-3 pages first üëÄ Use preview extensively before full export üìä Monitor resource usage during export ‚úÖ Verify outputs before deleting source data üìù Document settings for reproducible results

The Auto Backup feature in the Gruhanaksha QGIS plugin provides comprehensive automatic backup functionality for your QGIS projects and data layers. It ensures that your work is regularly saved and protected against data loss, with flexible scheduling and selective layer backup options.

‚è∞ Automatic Scheduling Configurable backup intervals from 1 to 1440 minutes Real-time countdown timer displayed in the QGIS toolbar Visual warnings before each backup operation üìÅ Flexible Backup Modes Single Backup: Maintains one backup copy, overwriting previous versions Multiple Backups: Creates timestamped backup folders with configurable retention üóÇÔ∏è Selective Layer Backup Choose specific vector layers to include in backups Project file is always included automatically Support for various formats (Shapefile, GeoPackage, SQLite, etc.) üìä Monitoring & Logging Detailed backup logs with timestamps Session-based logging for tracking backup activities System tray notifications (when minimized) üñ•Ô∏è User Interface Integrated toolbar timer widget Tabbed interface for settings and logs System tray icon for background operation notifications
Open QGIS with the Gruhanaksha plugin loaded. Access the Tools Panel via Plugins > Gruhanaksha > Tools. Click the Backup button in the Tools Panel.

‚è±Ô∏è Backup Interval‚Äã Set the Backup Interval (in minutes) using the spin box. Range: 1-1440 minutes (1 minute to 24 hours). Default: 10 minutes. üìÇ Backup Location‚Äã Click Change Folder to select where backups will be stored. Default location: ~/QGIS_Project_Backups (user's home directory). The folder path is clickable to open the backup directory. üîÑ Backup Mode‚Äã Choose between: Single Backup: Overwrites the previous backup with each new one. Multiple Backups: Creates separate timestamped folders for each backup. When Multiple mode is selected, set Maximum Backups to Keep (1-100). Older backups are automatically deleted when the limit is exceeded. üóÇÔ∏è Layer Selection‚Äã Check Select All Layers to include all vector layers, or Manually select specific layers from the list. Note: The project file (.qgz/.qgs) is always backed up regardless of layer selection.

Click Start Auto Backup. The system will: Validate the backup folder (ensure it's writable). Save the current project. Begin the countdown timer. Display a toolbar timer widget showing remaining time.

Toolbar Timer: Shows countdown and status (click to open backup window). System Tray: Notifications appear when the window is minimized. Log Tab: View detailed backup history and any errors. Click Stop Auto Backup to halt the automatic process.
Click Backup Now for an immediate backup outside the scheduled interval. Useful for saving work before making major changes.

Setting Description Default Range Backup Interval Time between automatic backups 10 minutes 1-1440 minutes Backup Mode Single vs. Multiple backups Single - Max Backups Number of backups to retain (Multiple mode only) 10 1-100 Layer Selection Which layers to backup None selected All vector layers

‚ùó Error Message üí° Cause ‚úÖ Solution "Please save the project first" Project hasn't been saved to disk Save your QGIS project before starting backup "Backup folder is not writable" Insufficient permissions or invalid path Choose a different backup folder with write access "Failed to commit changes for layers" Editable layers have uncommitted changes Save or discard changes in affected layers "Failed to save project" Project file write error Check disk space and file permissions Timer not appearing in toolbar Toolbar creation failed Restart QGIS or check for plugin conflicts

‚úîÔ∏è Save First: Always save your project before starting auto backup. üìÅ Choose Location: Use a dedicated backup folder, preferably on a different drive. üóÇÔ∏è Select Layers: Only backup layers you actively work with to save space. ‚è∞ Set Interval: Balance between data safety and performance (10-30 minutes recommended). üìä Monitor Logs: Regularly check the log tab for any backup issues. üíæ External Backup: Use auto backup as a safety net, not your only backup solution.

üó∫Ô∏è Scenario: You're working on a cadastral mapping project and want to ensure your work is automatically backed up every 15 minutes. Save your QGIS project. Open Tools Panel ‚Üí Click Backup. Set Backup Interval to 15 minutes. Choose Multiple Backups mode, set Maximum Backups to 20. Select the key layers you want to backup (leave others unchecked). Click Change Folder and select D:\QGIS_Backups. Click Start Auto Backup. Notice the toolbar timer showing "14:45" countdown. Continue working; backups happen automatically in the background. Check the Log tab periodically to ensure backups are successful. üßÆ Result: Your project and selected layers are automatically backed up every 15 minutes to timestamped folders, with old backups cleaned up automatically, providing robust protection against data loss. üìå The Auto Backup system provides peace of mind by automatically safeguarding your QGIS work, combining flexibility with comprehensive protection. üõ°Ô∏èüíæ

deprecated:>v1.0.1 The Drawline in QGIS allows users to create baseline geometries (üìè lines or üü† circles) based on a user-defined distance. This tool helps in digitizing and mapping linear and circular features with precision.

Supports line üìè and circle üü† geometries. Allows users to enter a specific distance value üî¢ for precise placement. Provides snapping üß≤ to existing features for accurate alignment. Includes a preview mode üëÄ before finalizing the geometry. Supports multiple measurement units: üìê Meters üîó Metric Links üîó Guntur's Links
Click on the Baseline Tool üß≠ in the QGIS toolbar. The tool will be activated, and the mouse cursor will change accordingly.
üñ±Ô∏è Left-click on the map to select the starting point for the baseline. The tool will highlight the chosen location with a green marker üü¢.

A dialog box will appear prompting you to enter the distance üî¢. Select the desired unit of measurement üìè. Choose the geometry type: üìè Line: A straight segment of the specified distance. üü† Circle: A circular feature with the given radius. Click OK ‚úÖ to confirm.

Move the cursor to see a preview üëÅÔ∏è of the feature. The tool will display: ‚ûñ A dashed line for line geometry. üåÄ A dashed circle for circular geometry. üñ±Ô∏è Right-click to cancel ‚ùå if needed.
üñ±Ô∏è Left-click again to confirm the geometry. The feature will be added to the Baseline layer üóÇÔ∏è. The tool will automatically reset üîÑ for a new operation.

üß≤ Snapping Support: The tool will snap to existing features based on QGIS's snapping settings. üßÆ Length Attribute: Each feature stores its measured distance in the attribute table. ‚Ü©Ô∏è Undo Support: If needed, remove the last created feature and retry.
Ensure that the entered distance is greater than 0. Check that the distance value is within valid range (0.01 - 10,000 meters).
Verify that snapping is enabled üß≤ in QGIS settings. Adjust snapping tolerance for better results.
Ensure that the Baseline layer is editable ‚úçÔ∏è. If an error occurs, check the QGIS message bar ‚ÑπÔ∏è for details.

The Baseline Tool üß≠ is a powerful QGIS extension for efficiently creating linear and circular baseline features. By allowing precise distance input and real-time preview, this tool enhances the digitization workflow üöÄ.

Available from v2.0.0 This advanced tool allows you to interactively edit line and polygon geometries with exceptional control. You can either drag vertices freely or use a precision panel to set exact side lengths. It fully supports snapping and topological editing.
You must have a Line or Polygon layer selected. The layer must be in editing mode (pencil icon ‚úèÔ∏è activated).

Activate the tool. Left-click a line or polygon feature to select it. The tool displays vertices and side lengths. Choose your action: Drag a vertex: Click and drag any vertex to a new position. Open Length Panel: Ctrl+Left-click a vertex to open a dialog for precise length input. Apply the changes. Right-click to reset and select a new feature.
From your tool panel, click on Free Adjuster to activate the Freehand Adjuster. A message will appear: ‚ÄúClick feature ‚Üí drag vertex or Ctrl+click for length dialog...‚Äù

Left-click anywhere on a line or polygon feature. The tool will select the feature and display its geometry details: üî¥ Red circle markers will appear on every vertex. White length labels (with a black halo) will show the length of each segment.

Once a feature is selected, you can modify it in two ways: Method A: Freehand Dragging‚Äã Hover over a vertex marker. Click and hold the left mouse button. Drag the vertex to its new location. A red rubber band will show a live preview of the change. Release the mouse button to finalize the vertex position. If topological editing is on, any shared vertices from adjacent features will also move. Method B: Precise Length Panel (Ctrl+Click)‚Äã Hold the Ctrl key on your keyboard. Left-click on the vertex you wish to adjust. The Length Adjustment Panel will open.

This dialog gives you precise numerical control over the connected side lengths. Select Units: Choose your desired measurement unit from the dropdown (Meters, Feet, etc.). Enter Lengths: Input the new, exact length(s) for the sides connected to the vertex. Show Preview: Check this box to see a red rubber band preview of your changes on the map before applying them. Auto-Adjust (for Triangles): If you are editing a vertex with two connected sides, this option prevents errors. If you enter a length for one side that makes the triangle invalid, it will automatically calculate a valid length for the other side. Click Apply to confirm the new lengths and close the dialog.
documents.s: üü© Step 4: Using the Length Adjustment Panel

documents.t: While the tool is active, press the Q key on your keyboard. The displayed length units on the map labels will cycle through Meters, Feet, Yards, and Links.
After an adjustment, the tool is ready to edit another vertex on the same feature. To deselect the current feature and choose a new one, right-click anywhere on the map.

Element Appearance Meaning Vertex Markers üî¥ Red Circles Shows all editable vertices on the selected feature. Length Labels White text with black outline Displays the length of each segment in the current unit. Preview Rubber Band Thin red line Shows a live preview of the geometry as you drag or input lengths. Snap Indicator Magenta cross (default QGIS style) Appears when your cursor is snapping to a vertex or segment.

Message Meaning / Suggestion "No layer selected" / "Select a vector layer" The tool was activated without a valid layer. Select a line or polygon layer. "Point layers not supported" The active layer is a point layer. The tool only works on lines and polygons. "Layer is not editable" The layer is not in editing mode. Click the pencil icon ‚úèÔ∏è to enable editing. "Invalid Triangle" / "Sides too short" The lengths entered in the panel cannot form a valid triangle. Adjust the values or check "Auto-adjust".

For best results with shared boundaries, enable snapping and topological editing in your QGIS project settings. Zoom in close for better accuracy when selecting and dragging vertices. Press Q to match the tool's units to your project or survey data units. Remember to save your layer edits in QGIS when you are finished!

Select any other tool from the QGIS toolbars. Press the Esc key to cancel a drag-in-progress. üìå The Freehand Adjuster offers an unparalleled combination of speed and precision, making it the go-to tool for fine-tuning vector geometries with confidence. üó∫Ô∏è‚úçÔ∏è

The Master Panel is a user-friendly form in QGIS designed to help you easily enter and manage administrative details such as: District Mandal Name (in English) Panchayat Name Grama Panchayat Code Village (LGD) Code This panel is useful for surveyors, map editors, or government staff who regularly work with village-level maps and need to maintain consistency across maps, reports, and templates.

You can open the Master Panel from within QGIS toolbar. Right Click on Toolbar ‚ñ∂ Enable Gruhanaksha Toolbar ‚ñ∂ Click on the Master Panel icon in the Toolbar From Plugin Menu: Plugins ‚ñ∂ Gruhanaksha ‚ñ∂ Master Data Once opened, you will see a simple form with labeled fields and two buttons at the bottom: Clear and Update.

Field What to Enter Choose Your District Select your district from the dropdown list. Each entry is shown in English followed by the Telugu name in brackets. Mandal Name (English) Type the mandal name using English letters. For example: Anandapuram. Panchayat Name Type the name of the panchayat (village council). Grama Panchayat Code Enter the official code assigned to the panchayat. Village (LGD) Code Enter the LGD (Local Government Directory) village code.

Click the dropdown at the top labeled ‚ÄúChoose Your District‚Äù. Scroll and select your district. Each item is displayed in the format: District Name (‡∞§‡±Ü‡∞≤‡±Å‡∞ó‡±Å ‡∞™‡±á‡∞∞‡±Å), e.g., Srikakulam (‡∞∂‡±ç‡∞∞‡±Ä‡∞ï‡∞æ‡∞ï‡±Å‡∞≥‡∞Ç).

Fill out the other fields: Enter the Mandal Name using English letters. Provide the Panchayat Name, Grama Panchayat Code, and Village Code carefully. There is no need to worry about uppercase/lowercase‚Äîentries are automatically converted to Proper Case (e.g., rajam ‚Üí Rajam).

After filling in all the details, click the Update button at the bottom. A pop-up message will confirm: "Data has been successfully updated." üóÇÔ∏è Your data is now saved and can be reused by other QGIS tools, map layouts, or custom forms.
Click the Clear button to reset all fields. This is useful if you want to enter new data for a different area or correct mistakes.

‚úÖ Easy-to-use form with clear labels ‚úÖ Districts listed in both English and Telugu ‚úÖ Automatically remembers your last-used entries ‚úÖ Makes sure your inputs are consistently formatted ‚úÖ Saves time during repetitive map and report generation

You are preparing a land parcel map for the Kotturu Mandal in Srikakulam District. Open the Master Panel ‚Üí Select Srikakulam (‡∞∂‡±ç‡∞∞‡±Ä‡∞ï‡∞æ‡∞ï‡±Å‡∞≥‡∞Ç) ‚Üí Enter Kotturu, Pathapatnam, GP Code 1056, Village Code 112233. Click Update. Now, any map template or labeling script in QGIS can access these values automatically.

Make sure you click the Update button after filling in or changing any field. Otherwise, your data won‚Äôt be saved. When you reopen the Master Panel later, your previous entries will load automatically for quick editing. Only one set of values can be stored at a time. Updating will overwrite previous values.

Available from v2.0.0 The Plotter Widget is a crucial tool in the Gruhanaksha plugin, designed for accurately plotting points along a selected line feature. This tool is particularly useful in land surveying and FMB workflows for marking specific points like "Cut Points" and "Offset Points". It is available as a tab within the Plotter tool.

üìè Flexible Unit Conversion Meters Metric Links (1 = 0.2 meters) Gunter‚Äôs Links (1 = 0.201168 meters) Feet (1 = 0.3048 meters) Yards (1 = 0.9144 meters) üìç Point Plotting Cut Point: Plot a point at a specific distance along a selected line from either the start or end point. Bisect Point: Plot a point at a specific distance along a selected line without any offset. Offset Point: Plot a point perpendicular to the "Cut Point" at a specified offset distance. Extended Point: If the "Cut Point Length" is negative or greater than the line length, it plots a point by extending the line. üó∫Ô∏è Interactive Line Segment Selection Click directly on a line segment on the QGIS map canvas to select it. The start (üü¢) and end (üî¥) points of the selected segment are automatically marked for easy reference. Supports snapping for precise segment selection. üóÇÔ∏è Memory Layer Integration The plotted points are added to a new or existing memory layer named "Plotted Points". Points are categorized by type ("Cut Point", "Offset Point", "Extended Point") and styled for clear identification.
Open QGIS. From the main tool panel, open the Plotter tool. Select the Plotter tab.

Click the Select Segment button. The button will change to "Selecting..." and a status message will guide you. Click on a line segment on the map canvas to select it. The start point will be marked in green (üü¢). The end point will be marked in red (üî¥). ‚ÑπÔ∏è Use snapping for higher accuracy. You can right-click at any time to clear the segment selection.

üî£ a. Units‚Äã Choose the measurement unit for the lengths you will enter. Meters Metric Links Gunter‚Äôs Links Feet Yards üëâ b. Choose Point‚Äã Select the reference point on the line for plotting. üü¢ Start Point üî¥ End Point üìè c. Lengths‚Äã Cut Point Length: Enter the distance from the chosen point (start/end) along the line to place the "Cut Point". Offset Length: Enter the perpendicular distance from the "Cut Point" to place the "Offset Point".
Click Plot ‚ñ∂Ô∏è The tool will calculate and plot the "Cut Point" and "Offset Point" on the "Plotted Points" memory layer.
The newly created points will appear on the map, styled by their type.
Click the Clear Segment button to remove the selected segment and reset the tool for a new operation.

‚ùó Error Message üí° Cause ‚úÖ Solution "Please select a segment first." "Plot" was clicked before a segment was selected. Use the "Select Segment" button to select a segment. "Direction vector has zero length, cannot extend line." The selected segment has zero length. Select a valid segment with length. "Line segment has zero length, cannot calculate offset." The selected segment has zero length. Select a valid segment with length.

‚úîÔ∏è Ensure your line layer has a valid CRS. üìè Double-check your units to match the project's requirements. üíæ If you need to keep the generated points, right-click the "Plotted Points" memory layer and choose Export > Save Features As... to save it to a permanent file (e.g., Shapefile, GeoPackage).

üó∫Ô∏è Scenario: You need to mark a point 15 meters along a property line from its start, and then mark an offset point 5 meters to the left. Click Select Segment and click on the property line on the map. In the Plotter tab, set Units to Meters. Choose üü¢ Start Point. Set Cut Point Length to 15. Set Offset Length to 5. Click Plot. üßÆ Result: A "Cut Point" is created 15m from the start of the segment, and an "Offset Point" is created 5m away from the "Cut Point", perpendicular to the segment. üìå The Plotter Widget is an essential tool for precise point creation along lines, streamlining survey and cadastral mapping workflows. üó∫Ô∏èüìç

Available from v2.1.0 This tool provides a flexible and powerful way to create new point layers by either manually entering coordinates or importing them from a CSV file. It supports multiple coordinate formats (UTM, DD, DMS) and includes robust validation and preview features.
A QGIS project must be open. For CSV import, you need a CSV or text file with coordinate data.

Open the Tool from the plugin panel. Set the Target CRS for the new point layer. Choose an input method: Manual Input Tab: Select the coordinate format (UTM, DD, or DMS). Enter a single coordinate or paste multiple coordinates in the batch input. CSV Import Tab: Browse and select a CSV file. Configure CSV options (delimiter, header). Map the columns containing X and Y coordinates. (Optional) Preview the points to be created. Click "Create Points" to generate the new layer.
From your plugin panel or button (depending on how it's integrated), click to activate the Point Input Tool. The "Enhanced Point Creator" dialog will appear.

At the top of the dialog, you'll find the Target Coordinate Reference System selector. This CRS will be assigned to the new point layer that the tool creates. By default, it uses your project's CRS. You can change it to any other CRS. The tool will automatically transform all input coordinates to this target CRS.
Select either the "Manual Input" or "CSV Import" tab.

Use this tab to type or paste coordinates directly. üîπ Step 3A: Choose Coordinate Format‚Äã Select one of the three radio buttons: UTM Coordinates: For Easting and Northing values. Important: A second CRS selector will appear. Use this to specify the source CRS of your UTM coordinates (e.g., the UTM zone they belong to). The tool will use this to correctly transform them to the target CRS. Decimal Degrees (DD): For standard latitude and longitude (e.g., 78.12345, 12.98765). Degrees Minutes Seconds (DMS): For coordinates in D¬∞ M' S" format. üîπ Step 3B: Enter Coordinates‚Äã You have two options for entering coordinates: Option 1: Single Point Fill in the input fields for the selected format (X/Y, D/M/S, or Easting/Northing). The tool provides real-time validation feedback (‚úì or ‚ö†). Option 2: Batch Input Check the "Enable batch input" box. Paste a list of coordinates into the text area. The tool accepts coordinates separated by a comma, space, or tab. Each point should be on a new line. # Example Batch Input 78.123,12.345 79.456 13.678 80.789 14.012 The "Points to create" counter will update to show how many valid coordinate pairs were found.

Use this tab to create points from a spreadsheet or text file. üîπ Step 3C: Select and Configure CSV‚Äã Click "Browse CSV..." to select your file. Adjust the CSV options if needed: Delimiter: Choose the character that separates columns (comma, semicolon, tab, etc.). First row contains headers: Keep this checked if your file has a header row. Uncheck it if the first row is data. Encoding: Change this if your file uses a non-standard character encoding. üîπ Step 3D: Map Coordinate Fields‚Äã Once the CSV is loaded, the column headers will appear in the X/Longitude Field and Y/Latitude Field dropdowns. Select the column that contains the X (Easting/Longitude) data. Select the column that contains the Y (Northing/Latitude) data. Click "Auto-detect coordinate fields" to let the tool try to find them automatically based on common names like lon, lat, x, y, easting, etc. üîπ Step 3E: Preview CSV Data‚Äã A table at the bottom shows a preview of your CSV data. Use the "Preview limit" spin box and "Refresh Preview" button to control how many rows are loaded for preview.

(Optional) Click "Preview Points" to see a summary of the points that will be created without actually adding them to the map. Click the "Create Points" button. A new memory layer named Points_<EPSG_CODE> will be added to your QGIS project, containing the points you specified.

Clear Inputs: Use the "Clear All" button to reset all fields in the dialog. Validation: Pay attention to the validation icons (‚úì, ‚ö†, ‚úó) next to the manual input fields for instant feedback. CRS Awareness: Always double-check that your Target CRS is correct. For UTM input, ensure the Source CRS correctly matches the zone of your coordinates. Batch Format: When pasting batch coordinates, ensure there are no extra characters or empty lines that could cause parsing errors.
Simply close the "Enhanced Point Creator" dialog window. If you created a temporary memory layer, you can save it by right-clicking it in the Layers Panel and selecting Export > Save Features As....
This tool allows you to easily move polygon vertices or adjust side lengths directly on your QGIS map using a guided, click-based process. It's designed for simplicity, precision, and clarity.
You must be editing a polygon layer. Ensure the layer is in editing mode (pencil icon activated).

Click a polygon on the map. Click one of its vertices. Choose an operation from the dialog: Move a vertex by a given distance. Set the length of one side of the polygon. Click a direction on the map to apply your change. Confirm or cancel the operation.

From your plugin panel or button (depending on how it's integrated), click to activate the Unified Polygon Edit Tool. A message will appear: ‚ÄúClick polygon, then click a vertex, then follow prompts.‚Äù

Left-click anywhere inside a polygon. A message appears: ‚ÄúPolygon selected. Now click a vertex of this polygon.‚Äù Shows the lengths of all sides of the polygon If nothing happens: Ensure you're clicking on a polygon from an editable layer. Make sure the layer is in editing mode (pencil icon enabled). Zoom in to the polygon and left-click inside its boundary to select it.
Hover near the polygon‚Äôs edge; a green cross appears on a vertex. Click that highlighted vertex. If valid, a pop-up dialog appears to select the operation and distance/length.

You‚Äôll see two options: Move Vertex by Distance Move the selected vertex a certain distance in a direction you will choose on the map. Set Polygon Side Length Resize one side of the polygon to a specific length, keeping one vertex fixed. Enter a length in map units and press OK. warning ‚ö†Ô∏è Distance must not be zero. Side length must be positive.

A message appears: ‚ÄúClick to set move direction‚Äù or ‚ÄúClick to select side direction‚Äù Move your mouse to the desired direction. A blue preview line shows your adjustment. Click once to confirm the direction.
A confirmation dialog appears, showing: Distance and angle (for vertex move), or Old vs. new length (for side adjustment) Click Yes to apply the change, or No to cancel.
You can now start a new operation from Step 2. Or right-click anywhere on the map to reset the tool. A message appears: ‚ÄúReady. Right-click to reset, or left-click to start new operation.‚Äù

Message Meaning / Suggestion "No polygon found" You didn‚Äôt click inside a valid polygon. Try again. "Layer Not Editable" Enable edit mode for that layer (click the pencil icon). "No vertex found" You clicked too far from a vertex. Zoom in and try again. "Invalid side length" Selected side is too short or undefined. Pick another vertex.

Zoom in close for better accuracy when selecting vertices or directions. The green dot shows the selected vertex. The orange X shows your direction click. The preview lines help visualize before confirming.
Just select any other QGIS tool or press the Escape key/ Right click

The Property Parcel Map Generator is a QGIS Processing Algorithm that automates the generation of parcel-wise Property Parcel Maps. It uses plot and built-up shapefiles to generate map-ready outputs with symbology, labels, and atlas setup.
To avoid errors and ensure smooth tool operation, complete the following setup steps:
Your QGIS project must be saved (.qgz) before running the tool. All output files will be created relative to the saved project folder.
Both plot and built-up shapefiles must use the same CRS.
The plot shapefile must contain: A unique parcel ID field Area in square yards and square meters fields The built-up shapefile should: Contain polygons that lie within the plot boundaries
Plot and Built-up layers must be different. Using the same layer for both inputs will cause errors.
documents.s: ‚úÖ 4. Do Not Use the Same Layer for Plot and Built-up

documents.t: Parameter Description Example Choose Plot Area Shapefile Polygon layer with land parcels. plot_area.shp Property Parcel Number Field Field used to identify each parcel. prop_id Plot Area in Square Yards Field Area field in square yards. AREA_SQYRD Plot Area in Square Metres Field Area field in square meters. SHAPE_Area Choose Built-up (Plinth) Area Shapefile Built-up polygon layer inside plots. builtup.shp District Name (English) Choose your district. Srikakulam Mandal Name Name of the Mandal. Tekkali Grama Panchayat Name Name of the Panchayat. Anandapuram Grama Panchayat Code Panchayat code. 123456 Village LGD Code Village code (LGD). 567890
Follow these steps to successfully use the Svamitva PPM Generator:
Ensure your plot area shapefile and built-up area shapefile are ready. Both layers must use the same CRS as your QGIS project. Your QGIS project must be saved before running the tool.

In QGIS, go to: Processing ‚ñ∂ Toolbox ‚ñ∂ Gruhanaksha ‚ñ∂ PPM Generation Double-click the tool to launch the input form. or Click on the Icon in the Toolbar or From Plugin Menu: Plugins ‚ñ∂ Gruhanaksha ‚ñ∂ PPM Generation
Select your plot and built-up shapefiles. Choose the correct fields for Property ID, Area in Yards, and Area in Meters. Fill in district, mandal, panchayat, and village code details.

Click Run. The tool will: Validate inputs and CRS Add calculated fields (Ref_Col, Length, Area) Create boundary/exploded lines and vertices Save new layers to the project directory Apply styles from QML files Label the parcels Load a print-ready A4 Atlas template
You will see new layers in the Layers Panel: Plot_ExplodeLines, Builtup_ExplodeLines, Plot_Shapefile, Builtup_Shapefile, Plot_Vertices etc. Check for labels and colors applied automatically.
Go to Project ‚ñ∂ Layout Manager Open A4_PPM_TEMPLATE Click Atlas ‚ñ∂ Preview Atlas Use Atlas ‚ñ∂ Export as PDF or Print

Output File Description Plot_Boundary.shp Boundary of plot areas Plot_Shapefile.shp Plot area shapefile Builtup_Shapefile.shp Intersected built-up shapefile Plot_ExplodeLines.shp Exploded lines with length Builtup_ExplodeLines.shp Built-up exploded lines Plot_Vertices.shp All vertices of plot polygons Builtup_Boundary.shp Boundary of built-up A4_PPM_TEMPLATE Print layout ready for Atlas export
All output layers are saved inside the same folder where your .qgz project file is saved. If your project is not saved, the tool will raise an error.

Error Solution CRS Mismatch Ensure both layers and project have same CRS (e.g., EPSG:32645) Same Layer for Plot and Built-up Use two different shapefiles Missing Style File Check if assets_folder contains all .qml and .qpt files Unsaved Project Save the QGIS project before running the tool

Use clean and properly named fields in your input layers. Don't rename files to reserved names like Plot_ExplodeLines, Builtup_ExplodeLines, Plot_Shapefile, Builtup_Shapefile, Plot_Vertices. Save the QGIS project and keep it organized before starting. You can customize .qml and .qpt styles to match your district‚Äôs format.
If you encounter issues: Recheck your inputs and field names. Ensure all style/template files exist.

The Tools Panel is a floating window in the Gruhanaksha QGIS plugin that provides quick access to a suite of specialized tools for land surveying, mapping, and data management. It serves as a central hub for activating various widgets and tools essential for cadastral and geometric operations.

üìê Plotter Tool Launches the Combined Plotter Widget for advanced geometric plotting, including triangles and point calculations. üîß Adjuster Tool Activates the Polygon/Line Adjuster for interactive geometry reshaping and side length adjustments. üéØ Free Adjuster Tool Enables the Freehand Adjuster for precise, unconstrained vertex-level editing of geometries. üíæ Backup Tool Opens the Backup Plugin for automated project saving and comprehensive backup management. üìè Aligner Tool Activates a two-point transformation tool to move, rotate, and scale features. üìç Point Input Tool Opens a dialog to create point layers from manually entered coordinates or CSV files.
Open QGIS with the Gruhanaksha plugin installed. From the QGIS menu, go to Plugins > Gruhanaksha > Tools. The Tools Panel window will appear as a floating widget titled "Tool Panel".

The panel contains a group box labeled "Tools" with buttons for each available tool: Plotter: Click to open the Combined Plotter Widget. Adjuster: Click to activate the Polygon/Line Adjuster tool. Free Adjuster: Click to activate the Freehand Vertex Adjuster tool. Backup: Click to open the Backup Plugin interface. Aligner: Click to activate the two-point Aligner tool. Point Input: Click to open the coordinate creation dialog. Each button will launch its respective tool or widget. Some tools may require a project to be saved first.

Opens the Combined Main Widget, which includes tabs for: Triangle plotting and calculations. Point plotting along lines with offsets. Geometric constructions for survey work. Requirements: A QGIS project must be open and saved.

Activates the Unified Geometry Edit Tool, allowing users to: Select a polygon or line and one of its vertices. Move the vertex by a specific distance or set a segment's length. Perform precise, guided edits on vector layers. Requirements: An editable line or polygon layer.

Activates the Vertex Tool for freehand adjustments, enabling: Precise, unconstrained drag-and-drop editing of individual vertices. Length adjustment of connected sides via a dialog (Ctrl+click a vertex). Detailed control over point positions with live length feedback. Requirements: An editable line or polygon layer.

Launches the Backup Plugin, providing: Automated project backups at set intervals. Comprehensive save options for project files and associated layers. Timer-based saving to prevent data loss. Requirements: A QGIS project must be open and saved.

Activates the Aligner tool, which allows you to: Translate, rotate, and scale vector features. Map two "source" vertices from your feature to two "target" points on the map. Perform two-point georeferencing-style transformations. Requirements: An editable Line or Polygon layer must be active.

Opens the Enhanced Point Creator dialog, which allows you to: Create a new point layer from manually entered coordinates (UTM, DD, DMS). Import points from a CSV file and map coordinate fields. Preview points before creation. Requirements: A QGIS project must be open.

‚ùó Error Message üí° Cause ‚úÖ Solution "Project not saved" Attempting to use tools without saving the project first. Save your QGIS project before accessing tools. Tool fails to launch Plugin components not properly loaded. Restart QGIS or reinstall the plugin. No response on button click Layer or feature selection issues. Ensure an appropriate, editable layer is selected for the specific tool.

‚úîÔ∏è Always save your project before using tools to avoid data loss. üìê Select appropriate, editable layers and features before activating geometry-related tools. üíæ Regularly use the Backup tool to protect your work. üîÑ Close unnecessary tool windows to maintain QGIS performance. üìå The Tools Panel streamlines access to essential surveying and mapping tools, enhancing productivity in QGIS-based land management projects. üó∫Ô∏èüõ†Ô∏è

Available from v2.0.0 The Triangle Widget is a powerful tool within QGIS designed for constructing triangles from a known baseline and two side lengths. üìê This widget is indispensable for land surveying, particularly in FMB (Field Measurement Book) workflows, where plots are often demarcated using triangulation. It is available as a tab within the Plotter tool.

üìè Flexible Unit Conversion Meters Metric Links (1 = 0.2 meters) Gunter‚Äôs Links (1 = 0.201168 meters) Feet (1 = 0.3048 meters) Yards (1 = 0.9144 meters) üñ±Ô∏è Interactive Baseline Definition Two-Point Selection: Select two points directly on the QGIS map canvas. Fixed-Length Baseline: After selecting the first point, press the L key to define a precise baseline length and unit, then click on the canvas to set its direction. Supports snapping for precise point placement. üìê Triangle Construction Define the lengths of the two sides extending from the baseline. Choose the triangle‚Äôs orientation (Left or Right of the baseline). üëÅÔ∏è Live Preview A real-time rubber band preview of the triangle is displayed on the map as you adjust the lengths and orientation. üóÇÔ∏è Memory Layer Integration The final triangle is drawn on a new or existing memory layer named "Triangle Lines". üõ°Ô∏è Robust Error Handling Prevents the creation of invalid triangles by checking the triangle inequality theorem. Provides clear, interactive feedback via a status label.
Open QGIS. From the main tool panel, open the Plotter tool. Select the Triangle tab.

You have two ways to define the baseline: Option A: Interactively Select Two Points‚Äã Click the Select Points button. The button will change to "Selecting..." and a status message will guide you. Click two points on the map canvas to define the baseline. The first point will be marked in green (üü¢). The second point will be marked in red (üî¥). A solid blue line will show the final baseline. ‚ÑπÔ∏è Use snapping for higher accuracy. You can right-click at any time to reset the point selection. Option B: Use a Fixed Length‚Äã Click the Select Points button. Click the first point on the map canvas (the green point üü¢). Press the L key on your keyboard. A dialog will appear. Enter the desired Length for the baseline and select the Unit. Click OK. Move your mouse on the canvas to orient the baseline. A dashed line will show the preview. Click a second time to set the direction and finalize the baseline's end point (the red point üî¥).

üìè a. Lengths‚Äã üü¢ Start Side Length: Enter the length of the side originating from the first (green) point. üî¥ End Side Length: Enter the length of the side originating from the second (red) point. üß≠ b. Orientation‚Äã Choose the direction to draw the triangle relative to the baseline: Left Right üî£ c. Units‚Äã Choose the measurement unit for the side lengths. This can be different from the unit used for the baseline. Meters Metric Links Gunter‚Äôs Links Feet Yards
Click Draw Triangle ‚ñ∂Ô∏è The tool calculates the apex and draws the three sides of the triangle on a memory layer named "Triangle Lines".
The newly created triangle will appear on the map. The "Triangle Lines" layer will contain three line features representing the sides of the triangle ("Base Line", "Start Side", "End Side").
Click the Clear Points button to remove the selected baseline and reset the tool for a new operation.

‚ùó Error Message üí° Cause ‚úÖ Solution "Please select two points first." "Draw Triangle" was clicked before a baseline was defined. Use the "Select Points" button to define the baseline. "No active layer to determine CRS." No layer is active in the Layers panel. Select or activate a layer in your project to provide a Coordinate Reference System. "Invalid side lengths. Triangle cannot be formed." The entered side lengths violate the triangle inequality theorem. Adjust the side lengths to form a valid triangle. "Second point must be different from first point." The start and end points of the baseline are the same. Ensure the two selected points for the baseline are in different locations.

‚úîÔ∏è Use snapping to ensure the baseline aligns perfectly with existing features. ‚å®Ô∏è Press the L key when you need to create a baseline of a precise, known length. üìè Double-check your units to match the project's requirements. üëÅÔ∏è Use the live preview to visualize the triangle before drawing. üíæ If you need to keep the generated triangle, right-click the "Triangle Lines" memory layer and choose Export > Save Features As... to save it to a permanent file (e.g., Shapefile, GeoPackage).

üó∫Ô∏è Scenario: You need to plot a triangular parcel of land. You have a known baseline on your map, and the other two sides are 30m and 40m. Click Select Points and click the two ends of the baseline on the map. Set üü¢ Start Side Length to 30. Set üî¥ End Side Length to 40. Set Orientation to Right. Set Units to Meters. Click Draw Triangle. üßÆ Result: A new triangle is drawn on the "Triangle Lines" layer, with the apex 30m from the start point and 40m from the end point, on the right side of the baseline. üìå The Triangle Widget simplifies the creation of triangulated geometries, making it an essential tool for accurate and efficient cadastral mapping and survey data processing. üó∫Ô∏èüìç
Save the Project for Bhukamatha to work as intended (as Bhukamatha is dependent on the project sources) To save the project use shortcut Ctrl+S or use the save icon in the toolbar
Proper Zone selection for the project and Layers is important and must be done
